importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The year 2025 is highlighted as a period of intense weather-related disasters, including floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US, underscoring the urgency for improved early-warning systems globally.

keyTakeAways: Nearly half of all countries lack effective early-warning systems for extreme weather events, leaving millions—particularly in developing nations—vulnerable.
Disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems, with 90% of fatalities in the past 50 years occurring in developing countries.

Over the last decade, the number of countries using multi-hazard early warning systems has increased from 52 to at least 108, but still, half of the assessed 62 countries have only basic capacity or less.
The situation is most severe in fragile, conflict-affected, and violence-prone regions.
Progress is being seen in Africa, where more countries are adopting functioning websites and standardized alerts.
The WMO emphasizes that early warning leads to early action, and its goal is not just to issue warnings but to empower communities to respond effectively.
Real-world examples such as the evacuation of Blatten, Switzerland, due to a monitored glacier collapse in May 2025, demonstrate the life-saving potential of early warning systems.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO), under the United Nations, has issued a global call to action to address severe gaps in early-warning systems for extreme weather events, noting that nearly half of all countries lack adequate infrastructure. With over 2 million deaths from weather, water, and climate-related disasters in the past 50 years—90% of which occurred in developing nations—the WMO stresses that early warnings are critical to saving lives and protecting infrastructure. Despite progress in early-warning adoption (from 52 to 108 countries in the last decade), assessments reveal that half of 62 evaluated countries have only basic or no capacity, with the situation being most dire in conflict-affected regions. The article highlights real-world examples such as the successful evacuation of Blatten, Switzerland, due to a monitored glacier collapse in May 2025, and widespread disasters in Pakistan, Nigeria, South Korea, and southern Europe, all underscoring the urgent need for improved, accessible, and standardized early-warning systems globally.
title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’
